title: What would it take to bring down the internet? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it possible?  Yes. but it is highly unlikely.  The internet as a whole is a framework of many independent networks controlled, run and maintained by different people and institutions. It is designed to be redundant which implies that even if one portion of this huge network goes down other users can still access their destination in most cases. But there are some examples of large scale shut down -  In late 2006 Asia experienced a series of earthquakes that damaged undersea cables that caused wide Internet and phone related issues in that part of the world. However, the remainder of the world still had access to the Internet. Governments can setup firewalls and other protection schemes to prevent users from accessing pages on the Internet or totally block access to the Internet.  For example, in 2011 the Egypt government shut down the Internet several times during protests to prevent any information leaking out onto the Internet. However, even during this strict shutdown, citizens were still able to find ways to access the Internet.  Sources : How Egypt shut down the internet - Telegraph; Worst Internet disasters of the decade  Further if you see this TED talk - The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B given by Internet pioneer Danny Hillis you get inclined to think that yes this is possible. Danny believes that internet wasn't designed for this kind of scale, and urges that we should be ready with a plan B. Also see : Knowing How the Global Internet Works - And How It Can Crash There is a Reddit thread that discusses this same question - Can the Internet (or at least the World Wide Web) crash, or fail globally? What could cause that?   Skeptics of a large-scale Internet crash scenario have plenty of ammunition for their argument. After all, what we call the Internet is actually a network of millions of other networks, massively redundant, the most sophisticated communications matrix in the history of technology. There's no way it can crash. Right? When someone says 'What could cause it?", the safest reply is that it's exactly what we don't know. It could be anything from a global catastrophe to a new cyber attack that can globally affect computers using the internet.  in any system, it's impossible to root out every conceivable problem. If the circumstances are right, you get a catastrophe. Thanks for the A2A.

Any man made network the size and complexity of the Internet will have a handful of major choke points and handfuls of minor choke ones.  As these are removed, the network will fragment into smaller and smaller chunks.  So the question is how much fragmentation would be equivalent to taking down the Internet?  My guess is below ten well chosen points could cause the net to be unusable for most things.   Most, if not all, of these points are fairly well protected in the real and digital world.  Physical damage of that magnitude would mean something so severe that I don't know if the Internet would be our main concern.  Digital damage would require a number of well crafted and highly organized zero day attacks. That said, the Internet is more likely to be harmed by an indiscriminate worm.  It was very noticeable way back in the day of the Morris worm.  If someone were to create an equivalent with a zero day that attacked any of the major components used today, we could be down for days.

Physically disabling all the core DNS servers would do a pretty good job for a few hours. It wouldn’t actually “shut down” the rest of the net, but it would make it inaccessible for most people. Longer term, you’d have to do things like cutting multiple undersea fiber cables and blowing up a bunch of physical peering points. And there would still be separated pieces that would probably work pretty well individually. Bear in mind that one of the original design goals of the ARPAnet was to design a network that could survive a nuclear war.

The internet was designed by the US during the cold war after the Russians sent a man up into space. The idea behind it was to get the scientists talking about inventions.  However, they had a problem.  The Russians could easily destroy communication methods (blow up a telegraph tower), so  they needed a way around this; the Internet. If a computer is destroyed the whole internet doesn't collapse, in fact if a whole country no longer had internet the rest of the world would be able to communicate. Data is sent around in packets from computer to computer until it reaches its destination. If one computer is broken on the root that a packet is travelling down, then it simply finds another way. Sure it is possible to destroy the internet. But I not sure whether it would be destroyed because something better came along or simply some other massive change in the digital world.

The basic structure of the internet was designed to survive a nuclear war. While a lit if the local distribution nodes may go down the system is so redundant that it data gets on the net it will get to the operating needed nearest you. To bring it down entirely would take a multinational attack at many places at once. And at that it would only be down for as long as the engineers to get in it and wipe our whatever malware brought it down.

Its important to remember that the "Internet" doesn't exist as anything more than an agreement as to how discrete networks exchange traffic (Internet Protocol).  In that regard its not possible to take down the Internet, but it is possible to affect large parts of a specific network as well as the points that networks normally use to exchange traffic.  The original idea behind the Internet was to produce a network that could survive widespread damage and automatically discover new routes when the preferred one(s) were disrupted.
